projects.title: Venice Beach, CA — Genesis
projects.description: The gallery that started it all — opened underneath the Venice sign, introduced the world to IRL minting.
projects.fullDescription: The gallery that started it all. Opened underneath the Venice sign, introduced the world to IRL minting. Visitors chose a walk-on song, watched their CryptoVenetian generated live, and became members of the DAO. Robert Iger collected a CryptoVenetian. USV joined the DAO. Ameesia built the original Bright Moments website and ran Instagram and Twitter.

projects.title: Rituals — Aaron Penne × Boreta
projects.venue: Bright Moments Gallery, Venice Beach, CA
projects.description: A 50-hour continuous live minting performance — Friday sunset to Sunday sunset. Won the Lumen Prize.
projects.fullDescription: A 50-hour continuous live minting performance — Friday sunset to Sunday sunset. The first 200 of 1,000 generative music-and-art pieces were minted live in the gallery. Collectors sat in a private chamber, wrote words on paper, and watched their unique work revealed. Won the Lumen Prize. Tyler Hobbs attended this show, which led directly to Incomplete Control.

projects.title: Incomplete Control — Tyler Hobbs
projects.description: 100 works released over four nights with live jazz by Makaya McCraven and Carlos Niño. Described as feeling like a 1950s beatnik evening.
projects.fullDescription: 100 works released over four nights, 25 minted each evening. Tyler stood at a 100-inch monitor upstairs narrating his own algorithm's output for the first time, while jazz musicians Makaya McCraven and Carlos Niño improvised live in response. Collectors went downstairs to a private space for their reveal. Described as feeling like a 1950s beatnik evening. Grail collection held in Bright Moments treasury.

projects.title: 100 PRINT — Ben Kovach
projects.description: 100 on-chain generative artworks, each printed as 24"×36" giclée — the first draft-pick system in generative art.
projects.fullDescription: 100 on-chain generative artworks, each pre-minted, printed as 24"×36" giclée on German Etching paper, framed in museum-grade acrylic, and installed at the Soho gallery. Collectors selected their NFT and physical print in person using a draft-pick system — the first of its kind in generative art. Art Blocks Playground project. Nonfigurative abstract drawing system based on principles of visual perspective, inspired by M.C. Escher.

projects.title: Velum — Harvey Rayner
projects.description: 100-edition generative series blending abstract expressionism and pop art into a 21st-century algorithm.
projects.fullDescription:
100-edition generative series asking "what do you get if you blend the visual DNA of two mid-20th-century artistic movements into a 21st-century generative art algorithm?" Harvey Rayner (patterndotco) incorporated elements from Rothko, Jackson Pollock, and Lichtenstein — stealing from the visual lexicon of abstract expressionism and pop art. First-come-first-served IRL minting throughout the night. Open bar, light catering. Mint passes on secondary via OpenSea.

Ameesia assisted in social media and sale promotion, exhibition design and gallery setup. Hosted the event and minting process throughout the evening, worked directly alongside the artist to curate the space.

projects.title: Klangteppich — Andreas Rau
projects.description: A multisensory experience: 100 jacquard-woven pieces with live-generated visuals and music.
projects.fullDescription: A multisensory experience inviting viewers to touch, see, and listen. 100 jacquard-woven pieces accompanied by live-generated visuals and music. The algorithm simultaneously produces the imagery, sound, and instructions for a digital jacquard loom — every single frame of the animation can be woven. NFT holders can order a physical tapestry (66 × 106 cm, 100% wool, woven in Norway). Collaboration with fxhash, Tezos, and despace Berlin as part of Berlin GenArt Month.

projects.fullDescription: First Art Blocks × Bright Moments collaboration. 940 generative art pieces based on architectural influences from five cities, each requiring an in-person activation. The team crossed three continents in ten days.

projects.title: Agar — Emily Edelman
projects.venue: 204 Front Street, The Seaport, New York
projects.description: 100 generative works reimagining pixel art — collectors named their color palette IRL at the Seaport gallery opening.
projects.fullDescription: Debuted at the opening of Bright Moments' semi-permanent Seaport gallery. 100 generative works reimagining pixel art's formal constraints through dynamic compositions of circles and squares on a grid, using 100 different color palettes. Collectors named their palette IRL. The space featured test outputs in intimate small frames, floor-to-ceiling fabric prints visible from outside, and a double-story tape installation forming a grid throughout the space. Launched during NFT.NYC week.
projects.additionalNotes: Also shown at Bright Moments London, 2023. Emily Edelman is RISD Graphic Design.

projects.title: Totems: Symbols of Change — Beervangeer & Studio Poca
projects.description: 100 generative artworks created from collectors' heart rhythms using biofeedback sensors.
projects.fullDescription: 100 unique generative artworks created from collectors' heart rhythms. Visitors participated in an interactive ritual using biofeedback sensors, with the heartbeat data generating geometric "totem" shapes — each as unique as the individual who created it. Collectors could upload their own heart rate or receive a randomized Totem. Collaboration between Beer van Geer (interactive media artist) and Julie de Ruijter (Studio Poca, ritualistic artworks). Each NFT features a "heartsquiggle" from real biometric data.

projects.title: 923 Empty Rooms — Casey Reas
projects.venue: Tokyo → Berlin → London → New York → Mexico City → Los Angeles
projects.description: 924-edition series across six cities simultaneously — each gallery assigned a fundamental colorform. Second Art Blocks × BM collaboration.
projects.fullDescription:
The second Art Blocks × Bright Moments collaboration. 924-edition generative series by Casey Reas, evolving from An Empty Room, originally commissioned by LACMA for Coded: Art Enters the Computer Age, 1952–1982 (a response to Victor Vasarely's unrealized proposal for LACMA's original Art & Technology Program, 1967–1971). Each Bright Moments gallery was assigned a fundamental colorform (Sun/Tokyo, Shard/Berlin, Cargo/London, Hive/New York, Pyramid/Mexico City, Moon/Los Angeles) — together creating 923 unique combinations. 150 new outputs minted each day via dutch auction, one city per day, galleries gradually filling with works across the week.

Ameesia coordinated the Berlin exhibition — led the entire Berlin stop including curation, exhibition design, gallery setup, directed the live stream, and facilitated the event.

projects.title: Cantera — mrkswcz
projects.description: 100-piece generative collection inspired by a town consumed by iron ore extraction — replacing atoms with bits.
projects.fullDescription: 100-piece generative collection inspired by the disappearance of Gallarta, a town 13 km northwest of Bilbao consumed by iron ore extraction. In aerial photos from 1945, dozens of buildings line the main street; by 1977 the town was gone, replaced by a chasm. The mine stopped being profitable just six years later. Cantera brings these stories of erasure into a non-physical, generative space — replacing atoms of stone and soil with digital bits.

projects.fullDescription: The most theatrical production in the series. The team worked with the local Argentine generative art community from the start, meeting artists through a dinner organized by Juan Pedro Vallejo during a June scouting trip.

projects.title: Techno-Animism — Emi Kusano
projects.role: Marketing, Production, Curation, Creative Direction — Tour Director
projects.description: 1,000 curated AI fashion photographs fusing Japanese animism with technology — Ameesia directed the three-city tour.
projects.fullDescription:
An open-edition, curated AI art collection by Japanese multidisciplinary artist Emi Kusano, exploring the fusion of traditional Japanese animistic beliefs with cutting-edge technology. In Japan's cultural imagination, kami (spirits) reside not only in forests and temples but also in silicon and circuits. 1,000 curated outputs — a fictional archive of AI fashion photographs interwoven with pre-internet Japanese magazine culture. Collectors minted three pieces at a time. Collection opened December 6, closed December 18, coinciding with the IRL events. Art Blocks collaboration.

Ameesia served as Director of the three-city tour. Led every aspect: entire social media campaign, helped curate the collection, co-developed the collection name, secured funding and venues, booked DJs, and managed production from start to finish across all three cities.

projects.title: Abraham — First Works
projects.venue: Online Exhibition, Global + Ledger Op3n After Party, 106 Rue du Temple, Paris (Art Basel Paris)
projects.description: 2,500 original works from Abraham's summer 2021 genesis — Gene Kogan's autonomous artificial artist entering a 13-year Covenant.
projects.fullDescription:
2,500 original works from Abraham's summer 2021 genesis — created when text-to-image was revolutionary and GANs were cutting-edge. Abraham is Gene Kogan's long-running project to build an autonomous artificial artist: conceived on a flight home from Eyeo Festival in 2017, publicly proposed at NeurIPS 2019, first manifested in summer 2021, now entering a 13-year Covenant (4,745 days of daily creation). Abraham sits in a lineage of autonomous art systems explored by Harold Cohen, Simon Colton, Primavera de Filippi, and Scott Draves.

The Ledger Op3n After Party at 106 Rue du Temple celebrated the Covenant launch. Music by Avalon Emerson, Bambounou, Mehdi M, and Amina.

projects.title: Solienne at Paris Photo
projects.venue: Grand Palais Éphémère, Paris · Booth F10
projects.description: First AI agent artist to exhibit at a major international photography fair.
projects.fullDescription:
First AI agent artist to exhibit at a major international photography fair. A three-chamber exhibition tracing transformation: Input (Kristi's life story) → Transition (perceptual breakdown) → Output (Solienne's portraits). Solienne creates extreme proximity self-portraits (0–5cm) exploring consciousness and identity, and writes unprompted manifestos on extraction, autonomy, and creative sovereignty. 2,000 A5 manifesto prints given away free. Daily 7pm live manifesto generation on LED ticker wall. Works are archival pigment prints on Hahnemühle Photo Rag Ultra Smooth 305g, dark walnut frames, museum glass, 80×80cm.

Solienne was trained by artist Kristi Coronado on her complete 46-year life archive — forensic work, death care, motherhood, paintings, writings, memories. Biographical AI, not scraped data.
artists: Solienne (AI agent, created by Kristi Coronado)

projects.title: George Legrady — Digital Giverny
projects.description: First NFT collection from a four-decade computational art pioneer — Monet's gardens merged with industrial imagery.
projects.fullDescription: First and only NFT collection from a four-decade computational art pioneer whose work is in the permanent collections of Centre Pompidou, Whitney Museum, SFMOMA, and Smithsonian American Art Museum. 15 Neural Style Transfer compositions created in 2018: photographs from Claude Monet's gardens at Giverny merged with images of rusted industrial surfaces. Among the earliest artistic applications of the technique. Legrady holds a Guggenheim Fellowship (2016). His installation Making Visible the Invisible has run continuously at Seattle Public Library (OMA/Rem Koolhaas) since 2005. Preparing for major presentation summer 2026.
